4.heading: Whiz-Bang.
4.title: Captain Whiz-Bang
4.author: by Diane Stanley.
notes: Summary (from OCLC): Captain Whiz-Bang spends the years of his youth as a champion cat, chasing dogs and jumping high fences, then ages gracefully into a purring lap-sitting cat.
A children's book decorated with comics art.

5.title: "Whiz-Bang Polar Express Will Melt Your Heart"
5.author: by Margaret A
5.appears_in: McGurk. p. E1, E7 in The Cincinnati Enquirer, Nov. 10, 2004.
notes: Review of the film The Polar Express.

6.heading: Whiz Bombs.
6.title: "The Flight of the Silver Saucers"
6.author: [No author]
6.series: Captain Wings) 10 p. in Wings Comics, no. 112
notes: Though the art is substantially the same, this story is a thorough re-write of the Captain Wings story in Wings Comics, no. 53 (Jan. 1945), where it is signed "L. Elias."

Summary: "Madam X" is a grounded bomber upon which "whiz-bombs" have been inappropriately mounted. It has been damaged and its crew is injured, and the plane is scheduled to be dismantled. A Japanese Zero crash-lands near the base, and a woman survives, managing to make the men think they've captured secret plans. After the squadron has left to take advantage of the plans, the woman steals a gun and kills the radio operator. The crew of Madam X figures out what has happened, and leaves sick bay in a suicide mission to spring the ambush the Japanese have set up. On page 7, a Japanese radioman says, "Silver disks
our greatest arsenal gone! Shoot down that plane at any cost!" The whiz-bomb shown in p. 1 does seem to be disc-shaped, though from the title and cover art we would expect flying saucer UFOs.

106.title: Whiz Comics
notes:
Anthology style comic book. Features include
  • Algernon (issue 120)
  • Beanpole Bertie (issue 72)
  • Bulletman (issue 106)
  • Captain Marvel (in every issue)
  • Colonel Corn and Korny Kobb (scattered issues from no. 102 to no. 153)
  • Colonel Porterhouse (issues 35-39)
  • Commando Yank (issue 102)
  • Companions Three (issue 15)
  • Cousin Egbert (issue 41)
  • Crime Smasher
  • The Culture Corner
  • Dan Dare (issues 1-22)
  • Doc Sorebones
  • Dr. Death (issues 154-155)
  • Dr. Voodoo (issues 7-34)
  • Freshman Freddy (most issues from no. 101 to no. 131)
  • Golden Arrow (every issue but no. 15 and no. 155)
  • Horace Hotstuff
  • Ibis, the Invincible (every issue but no. 107)
  • Jim and Jam (issue 113)
  • Kanvasback (issue 106)
  • Lance O'Casey (most issues)
  • Nick and Dick (issue 109)
  • The Peak of Pikes (issue 127)
  • Pee Wee Pete (issue 83)
  • Richard Richard, Private Dick (issue 50)
  • Scoop Smith (issues 1-6)
  • Skipper McGee (issue 40)
  • Spy Smasher (issues 1-75)
  • Whipper-Snappers
  • Whitey Whiskers and Daniel Boone, Jr. (issue 94)
  • Wicky and O'Shawnessy
  • Wilbur the Waiter
This list originates from the one in Howard Keltner's Index to Golden Age Comic Books (Detroit, Mich. : J. Bails, 1976)
